newsitem.title: USA: U.S. yield curve shows mkt doubts Fed - Dean Witter.
newsitem.headline: U.S. yield curve shows mkt doubts Fed - Dean Witter.

text.p: The steepening of the U.S. Treasury yield curve since the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged on May 20 reflects market concern the Fed may be softening its anti-inflation stance, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc said on Thursday.

"The spread between the bond-equivalent three-month bill and the 30-year bond had dropped to a low of 162 basis points on the day before the recently concluded Federal Open Market Committee meeting," said Dean Witter senior economist and first vice president Kevin Flanagan, who noted that spread now is "coming in at 190 basis points."

"This current level represents the widest reading for this measure since June of last year," Flanagan noted. "This renewed steepening of the Treasury yield curve appears to be the direct result of the Fed's decision to leave monetary policy on hold at the May 20th convocation."
The Dean Witter economist said such steepening reflected investors' doubts about "the credibility of the Fed's fight against inflation."

"This negative reaction from bond holders reflects the concern that the credit authorities are no longer being proactive but rather reactive in nature," Flanagan added. "The fear is that the Fed could be falling behind the curve."

Flanagan said if the expected slowdown does not materialize and May economic data -- mainly the payrolls -- come in strong, "the Fed's resolve and credibility will be questioned even further with higher open-market yields most likely being the direct result."
